text:
The search continues for the suspect 
in Wednesday's mass shootings in Maine.

And Israeli forces conducted 
another raid on northern Gaza

overnight as U.N. officials say fuel 
shortages are crippling relief efforts.

Good morning. I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

The search has continued through the night 
in Lewiston, Maine, for Army reservist Robert

Card. He's considered the prime suspect in 
Wednesday's mass shootings. NPR's Brian Mann

reports there have been no confirmed sightings 
of him and the community remains in lockdown:

A small army of police descended on one 
farmhouse last night outside Lewiston,

but no arrests were made, and Card remains 
on the run. He has been charged with murder

following Wednesday's shooting at a 
bowling alley and nearby bar that left

18 people dead. This week's violence 
caused Maine Congressman Jared Golden,

a Democrat, to reverse his opposition to 
banning military-style assault weapons:

To the people of Lewiston, I ask 
for forgiveness and support as I
seek to put an end to these terrible shootings.

Legislation that would reinstate 
the ban on military-style assault
rifles has been stalled in Congress for years.
Brian Mann, NPR News, Lewiston, Maine.

Israel says it conducted another brief raid into 
northern Gaza overnight. The Israeli military says

it targeted Hamas militants in response 
to Hamas attacks nearly three weeks ago.

The Israeli blockade of Gaza 
continues the United Nations

says its relief aid to Palestinians 
is collapsing. U.N. official Philippe

Lazzarini says relief workers need 
fuel badly and that's been cut off:

A few days ago, I warned that we will 
not be able to continue our humanitarian

operation if we do not get the fuel supply. My 
warning still stands. Over the last few days,

UNRWA has drastically limited its consumption 
of fuel, but this came at a cost — our team

had to make tough decision that 
no humanitarian workers should do.

Gaza health officials now say more than 
7,300 Palestinians have been killed in

Israeli military attacks. Israel says 
Hamas killed more than 1,400 people,

mostly Israelis, when militants 
attacked on October 7th.

Embattled Congressman George Santos will be back 
in federal court today. From member station WNYC,

Brigid Bergin reports the New York 
Republican is facing 10 new fraud charges:

He's accused of conspiring with his former 
campaign treasurer to file false reports with

the FEC that inflated his fundraising numbers, 
including a fictitious half-million dollar loan

Santos claimed to make to his own campaign 
when he only had $8,000 in his bank account,

according to prosecutors. He's also accused of 
stealing his donors' credit card information and

attempting to make thousands in charges. 
Some he masked as campaign donations and

others he funneled to his personal bank 
account. Santos pleaded not guilty to 13

earlier charges at an arraignment in May, 
and he continues to say he will not resign.
For NPR News, I'm Brigid Bergin, in New York.
This is NPR.
